Award.AwardTitle: Spatial and Temporal Regulation of Cytokinesis in the Early Embryo

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The generation of new daughter cells from preexisting cells is a fundamental property of life, and proper development and survival necessitates that cells execute mitosis and cytokinesis with high fidelity. In animal cells, cytokinesis occurs through the action of an actomyosin contractile ring, whose position is dictated by microtubules of the mitotic apparatus. While major inroads have been made towards identifying the constituents of the contractile ring, cytokinesis remains the only phase of the cell cycle where a unifying model has yet to be distilled from the plethora of approaches and model systems employed over the last century. This project seeks to examine how models proposed for spatiotemporal regulation of cytokinesis in somatic cells apply to the early embryo, where the large cell size and rapid division cycles pose challenges not faced by cells later in development. Questions to be addressed include how the chromosome passenger complex, which translocates from the centromere to the cell equator during anaphase, contributes to cytokinesis in cells where chromosomes are dispensable for cleavage plane determination. Additionally, the project will examine how microtubules contribute to cleavage plane determination by actively suppressing contractility at the polar regions of the cell. Lastly, the project will examine how the sequence of events leading to cytokinesis are coupled to the machinery of the cell cycle. These studies will be performed on sea urchin eggs and early embryos, whose optical clarity, amenability to physical and molecular manipulation, and sequenced genome afford the ability to ask unique questions regarding the spatial and temporal regulation of cytokinesis. The planned lines of experimentation will merge classical manipulations of cellular geometry with advanced imaging, molecular- and chemical biology. Together, these studies will make significant inroads into reconciling how mechanisms directing the spatial-and temporal regulation of contractile ring assembly defined in somatic cells work in larger, embryonic cells.

Broader Impact
The project will increase diversity of scientists in the cellular and developmental biosciences. New Mexico State University is a minority-serving institution, and the training of underrepresented minority- and first generation college students is a fundamental part of all activities in the PI's laboratory. Minority undergraduate- and graduate trainees, including visiting scientists from tribal colleges in New Mexico, will participate in all aims of the project. To recruit participants from tribal colleges, both the PI and students will make presentations at two year- and tribal colleges to generate interest in the study and interested participants will be invited to join the research team as summer trainees or as undergraduate students enrolled at New Mexico State University. Results from the study will be shared and broadly disseminated. Images and timelapse sequences generated by the research will be integrated with the educational mission of the PI, and in-class activities utilizing the sequences will be disseminated through peer-reviewed educational web portals.

Project Outcomes Report

Spatial and Temporal Regulation of Cytokinesis

MCB #0818729

 

Proper development and survival of all living organisms is dependent on a cell’s ability to correctly replicate the genome, and then segregate those genomic equivalents into two daughter cells. Once the cell has initiated chromosome segregation, the two daughter cells must be physically partitioned in a process known as cytokinesis. This project sought to understand how mitosis and cytokinesis division is regulated in embryonic cells, where the large cell volume creates special challenges not faced by smaller somatic cells. We examined several factors known to regulate the organization of microtubules that regulate the initiate cytokinesis in somatic cells, using a combination of live cell imaging with molecular, physical and biochemical manipulation. In particular, we tested the notion that the Chromosomal Passenger Complex is not required for cytokinesis in large embryonic cells, where the organization of microtubules differs from somatic cells. We found that in contrast to what had been previously proposed, the CPC was required for cytokinesis, and that these proteins were simply recruited to the cleavage plane via a different population of microtubules. Another factor required for cytokinesis, named Protein Regulator of Cytokinesis (PRC1), has been thought to help spatially regulate cytokinesis by bundling antiparallel microtubules from opposing spindle poles. However, under certain conditions, cells can be induced to attempt cytokinesis when the spindle has been collapsed to form a radial, monopolar spindle. Under these circumstances, microtubules are no longer organized in an antiparallel fashion, but when PRC1 was disrupted in these cells, cytokinesis was dramatically affected. Interestingly the loss of PRC1 had a much more dramatic effect on cytokinesis in cells with monopolar cells than in cells with normal, bipolar spindles, and our efforts to understand the role of PRC1 in cytokinesis continue. But these studies strongly suggested not only that PRC1 is the primary microtubule organizer for cytokinesis, but that it can organize these microtubules irrespective of their orientation.

 

The study mentioned above required that we generate cells with monopolar spindles, and this manipulation was also required for us to ask a separate question regarding the spatial regulation of cytokinesis. In order for create monopolar spindles in the embryos of marine invertebrates, we needed to create small molecules that would remain both soluble and membrane permeant in the harsh ionic conditions of seawater. In collaboration with an organic chemist, 30 novel small molecules were screened for their ability to inhibit spindle formation, and several candidates were identified that had increased activity over the parent molecule in both mammalian and echinoderm cells. Thus, we were able to generate a novel set of reagents that will be of use to investigators who wish to study spindle formation in non-mammalian model systems.

 

In addition to the research activities described above that probed the basic mechanics of cell division in animal cells, the PI was involved in a number of activities that integrated the project into education, training and outreach. Five PhD students and one MS student participated in the project, and of those four were underrepresented minorities. Undergrads were also actively incorporated into the project, with over a dozen students contributing to the project. Of those, four were summer students from NMSU’s BRIDGES program, which brings students from New Mexico’s tribal colleges to campus for a summer research experience.
